text: Trockener Geschmack nach wässrigem Bourbon. Muffig süß, minimale Herbe. Zum Ende etwas süßer, leicht brotig. Okay. 10/8/9/8/11/9

Bottle 330ml. @ [ (PBF XI) by oh6gdx - Petalax ]. [ As Füchschen Wenn Dä Omma Dat Wüsst (Vintage Burbon Ale) ].Clear medium amber color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, light beige head. Aroma is moderate malty, sweet malt, caramel, bourbon, laber larver, wood. Flavor is moderate sweet with a long duration, bourbon, laber larver, sweet malt, light caramel. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20160708]
 7-3-7-3-13

Bottle. Coconut, a bit less vanilla, ripe hazelnuts, hazelnut cream, subtle dried fruit and toasted notes. Sweetish and silky smooth, without any notable presence of tannins. Not too heavy, well balanced, with the typical drinkability of an altbier. Awesome stuff.
Brown, beige head, aroma of vanilla, coconut, banana, toffee, fun, malty, great, flavor of coconut, banana, toffee, great, vanilla, wood.
Bottle - dark copper color, small head. Taste is vanilla, wood, sherry, bourbon, dark malts, some chocolate. Very sweet, boozy finish. So and so.

0.33 l bottle from the brewpub, bottled in March 2015. Clear, dark brownish red with a medium large, frothy, almost stable, off-white head. Sweetish, malty, a bit oxidized aroma of caramel, raisins, vanilla, bourbon, hints of tobacco and some oak. Rather sweet and malty taste of caramel, vanilla, tobacco, bourbon, raisins and some oak, followed by a medium long, slightly bitter, a little warming finish. Above medium-bodied, slightly creamy mouthfeel, soft carbonation. Really good and very complex for that abv, reveals lovely barrel notes without them being too dominant and offers a full enough body to support them. Füchschen is definitely not my most favourite Alt, but this is tasty!

Shared with wim at his home. Hazy brown colored beer with small white head and no carbonation visible. Yeast poored in the glass. Alcoholic wooden hinted malty aroma. Finish is sweet alcohlic wooden hinted dry.

Amber colour, small off-white head. Aroma is vanilla, some mild bourbon, wood as well as mild sweet malts to it. Flavour is vanilla, alcohol, bourbon, some floral notes along with mild ripe fruitiness.

33cl bottle @PBF XI. 
Poured amber color with a thin white head. 
Bourbon in aroma at first, bready notes, malts. 
Flavor has Bourbon, wood, toffee, caramelly malt. Sweet, long finish.
330 mml bottle tasted on the 30/06/2016. Dark amber colour with a minimal beige head. Intense bourbon aroma with notes of caramel and wood. Taste is sweet malts, bourbon and wood. Next one please!
At Home along with Yves hazy brown colored body with a white head and a roasted malt vanilla hops aroma a roasted malt vanilla hops bitter sweet taste with a alcholic bitter finish

At a tasting, many thanks, small stable bubbly head, very dark hazy orange to brown color, aroma of toffee bourbon vanila fruitiness and pumpernickel bread, lots of caramel in flavor with bourbon, wood and vanila, light pleasant sourness. Tasty and highly enjoyable, not middle of the road.

Bottle sample at a tasting at troubless place. Thanks Tom C. Hazy amber-brown. Great aroma aroma of bourbon, caramel, cookies, vanilla, nuts. Sweet flavor with caramel, vanilla, bourbon, wood. Medium-bodied, rounded. Really good stuff.

Flasch(Hopfen & Malz, Berlin-Wedding):Deep ruby-amber coloured, presumably a bit hazy, bigger lacy off-white head; vanilla, caramel, wood, dried fruits and port in rich sweet nose; almost solid sweet-bitter flavour, medium bodied, not very soft; lingering - slightly drier - bitter and sweet-malty finish with, again, wanilla and vood and port-wine. Klobouk dolu! Far better than expected

Bottle shared with Rian and Mark. Many thanks to Gabriel (erzengel) for bringing this over for us last month. Copper with a lively off white head. I was little sceptical and expecting something gimmicky here, but this is a superb beer. All the classy long lagered smoothness of an Altbier, the extra body of a Sticke and superbly executed barrel ageing, with just the right Burbon notes along with subtle wood. Despite the age, the spicy hops still shine through. The best new wave German beer Ive tried to date.
Many thanks for this beer to Erzengel. Pours a dark amber beer with small head and good lacing. Aroma is vanile, malts, wood and floral.

Many thanks to Erzengel for sharing!

Pours hazy dark amber colour with a mid-sized beige head. Aroma of bourbon, sweet malt, caramel, toffee, vanilla. Taste of sweet roasted malt, caramel, tons of vanilla, bourbon, intense aroma, very nice!

0,33 l bottle out the big big box from kappldav123. Thanks a lot! A dark brown with a little bit reddish. Short living very small fine fomy head. Whisky and barrel wood on the nose. Taste starts dark berrie fruity with sweetness in the front row, followed by a alcoholic whisky sequence. Malty background, with present sweetness. Warming body. Not an Alt in it´s traditionell way but a very nice one interpretation!

The beer is great woody vanilla-smooth. Fresh bitter, intense vanilla with nice dry bitter Altbier. The smooth and slightly sweetish Bourbon wood is fitting great to the bitter and dry Altbier. Deep and Vanilla. Great!

Many thanks to erzengel for this special treat!! Pours a hazy orange/brown with a tan head. The smell is sweet bourbon, vanilla, dark fruit, oak. The taste is on par with the nose, fairly sweet with a dry woody aftertaste. Medium on body with with very silky carbonation. Great stuff!

Pours a dark brown color, revealing a darker red, ember glow, while held against the light. Has a decent head, collapsing to a crown of bubbly lacing, coating the whole surface of the glass.

Bourbon is the first thing I get, as for the aromas, while it is well entangled into bready malts. This leads to caramel, dried fig, molasses, resulting from its warm, oakie profile, topped off by a vanilla note. Apart from its typical, spicy caramel quality this almost reminds me of a barrel aged barleywine.

Has a medium, well fitting carbonation, unusual low for an Alt to highlight the beers bigger body in this, while not completely abandoning its refreshment. Especially on the mid-palate, a lively, but soft carbonation helps to prevent the malts from becoming overly heavy and sweet, complimenting stony, dry earth.

Tastes of caramel dipped oak chips, which get easily handled by whole grain bread during the beginning. As the flavors evolve, the Bourbon channels more flavors onto the palate, dried fruits, a note of pepper and wild honey, soothed by the warming barrel, which blends amazingly well into the malt foundation of the beer. Spices become even more apparent during the swallow, while resulting in an utmost clean, Alt typical finish, in which the malts prevail, while wooden spices still cut through, together with a glazed caramel note.

This is great, I like the idea of creating a barrel aged Barleywine-like Imperial Alt, decadent and sweet, while remembering its origin and sticking to its style. The distinguishing Füchschen spiced sweetness is certainly the perfect enabler for getting the most out of the Bourbon barrel, while soothing its warmth with a potent bread maltiness. The barrel addition has certainly a huge impact on the beers taste, while its mouthfeel remains as smooth and velvet as usual for an Alt, cushioning its spiced heat.

Bottle looks really good. Beer in the glass zippy, brownish, nice head. Fine malty strong aroma. Starts strong, malty, spicy, light alcoholic, not too intense. Fine woody notes. Warming malty finish. Quite drinkable. Nice one!

Bottle. Amber color. Toffee, bourbon and vanilla in the aroma. Malty sweet flavor with toffee and vanilla. Lots of whisky. The Kentucky bourbon has taken over control, with an indeed excellent result.
